greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = prime(n) - k! where k is the greatest number such that k! <= prime(n).
comment: How many times does each prime appear in this sequence?
The only value (prime(n) - k!) = 0 is at n=1, where k=2.
Are n=2, k=2 and n=4, k=3 the only occurrences of (prime(n) - k!) = 1?
There exist infinitely many solutions of the form (prime(n) - k!) = prime(n-t), t < n.
Are there infinitely many solutions of the form (prime(n) - k!) = prime(r_1)*...*prime(r_i); r_i < n for all i?
link: Jinyuan Wang, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
formula: a(n) = prime(n)- k! where k is the greatest number for which k! <= prime(n).
maple: f:=proc(n) local p,i; p:=ithprime(n); for i from 0 to p do if i! > p then break; fi; od; p-(i-1)!; end;
program: (PARI) a(n) = my(k=1, p=prime(n)); while (k! <= p, k++); p - (k-1)!; \\ _Michel Marcus_, Feb 19 2019
results.author: _Ctibor O. Zizka_, Apr 02 2008
